Elsa is a strong, determined woman who was not loved enough by her family or her husband but when things got tough, she got tougher.The Four Winds is a story about working against the odds, making a difference in the world, and helping strangers.  Elsa moves her children across the country to find a better life and does not find exactly what she expects.  She finds a community of people living together in poverty, she makes friends, she works alongside her friends, and she makes a difference to her community.Kristin Hannah is a must-read author.  If the Great Depression is not your thing find another of her books to read.  I recommend them all!
title: working against the odds and making a difference

author: Elaine
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2021
review_content: I loved this book. The strength of characters and the resolve to try and survive no matter what.  A single mother struggling to shelter and provide for her children during the absolute worst of times. The Dust Bowl and the Depression tried the souls of millions of people moving West to find work and falling victim to the wealthy growers for criminally unfair wages and conditions. Made me think twice about the times we are going through today in our Country and how we will come away stronger although so many have lost their battle.  An amazing read!!!!!
title: Riveting

author: Kelley Twardowski
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2021
review_content: " '...There will be more help in place in the morning.' 'From Communists?' 'I don't see anyone else here, do you?' ""She swung her arms as she walked to town. What could be better than skipping school to visit the library?  She'd red The Communist Manifesto this week and she was eager to find something equally enlightening."Teacher: "Open your American history books to page one-twelve.''Loreda...looked at the open book.  The chapter heading was the Founding Father and the First Continental Congress.Loreda raised her hand...''I'm interest in more recent history, ma'am.  The farmworkers here in California.  The anti-immigration policies that deported the Mexicans.  And what about workers' unions?"The teacher rapped her ruler down so hard it cracked.  "We do not talk about unionism here.  That's un-American.  We are lucky to have jobs that put food on our tables."Loreda: ''We don't need to learn about what old rich men did more than one hundred years ago.  The world is falling apart now."I cannot say this anymore clearly -  in this book, Kristin Hannah espouses the merits of Communism.  *eye.roll.*I have read three of her books prior to this one.  In all three - The Great Alone, The Nightingale, and On Mystic Lake - while I did like the books, I felt like the endings wrapped up quickly in very neat little package; but I did like the books over all.In The Four Winds -  I experienced the same feeling, but from the very start of the book.  The main character, Elsa is unloved and unappreciated by her family, she has poor self esteem, she gets taken advantage of by a boy from town, turns out, he doesn't love her as much as she loves him...it was all very predictable.  Fine.  Whatever.  But when she and her - not surprisingly - radical, upstart daughter begin to embrace the wonders of Communism -see pg. 365 Elsa: I thought you commies hated everything in America.  Jack: Not at all, he said solemnly.  We agree with the New Deal.  We believe in justice and fair wages and equal opportunity for all, not just the rich.  Communism is really just the new Americanism; I think it was John Ford, the director, who said that first.  At one of the early meetings of the new Hollywood Anti-Nazi League. - I'd had enough.I will not purchase any of this lady's books again.  If this is the kind of political propaganda she believes in and promotes, she is lucky to live in a country that defends free speech, free thought, free business.
title: If I could leave zero stars I would

author: Juno
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2021
review_content: I haven’t read one of her books in years.  This was highly recommended to me by a friend.  After reading 2/3 of the book I now know why I rejected her books years ago.  I will never read another book by her.  Very wordy to fill pages, political and boring.
title: Done with it!

author: SamT
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2021
review_content: Like many comments I have read, I have mixed feelings about this book. I thoroughly enjoyed the first 3/4 of the story. I found it fascinating,as I do with most of her work. However, when the political ideas on communism started moving its way into the story, it felt like the main point and the story faded into the background. Unfortunately, I just couldn’t finish the book. Kind of sad about it.
title: The first 3/4 of the book was good and then...

author: Linda Bartosik
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021
review_content: Hannah does it again. Her writing - just the right amount of description and conversation to move the story along. Not once did I have to skim through. Hannah is an amazing weaver of words, but an even more author of the human condition. My first Hannah book was Firefly Lane. I sat and cried and FELT for almost a day after finishing it. Then Night Road. Took my breath away. Now Four Winds. Here we are in these times again. The character Elsa exemplifies what we must become. We must be strong and not give up in the face of this pandemic. Thank you, Kristin, for giving us the gift of these words in these unprecedented times.
title: Amazing Book for Amazing Times

author: Margie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2021
review_content: This is one of the best books I have ever read in my life. It focuses on Elsa’s life. It takes place during the Great Depression. It tells of the Dust Bowl storms in Texas. It tells of migrant workers. Even though it is a novel, it brings history to life. The authors descriptions of places, people and events brought the story to life in a way that made me feel what the characters were experiencing. I highly recommend that everyone read this book. It will change how you look at life and make you appreciate what you have a whole lot more.
title: Outstanding

author: Sherry L. Maguire
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2021
review_content: Kristin Hannah had been one of my favorite authors for years, and I’d heard nothing but great reviews from close friends who have similar literary tastes as mine. Those are the only reasons I read this book through to the end. I did not need 200 pages to drive home the point that Elsa felt unloved. It was so belabored and depressing, I really did not want to read on. Although I learned quite a bit historically about the Dust Bowl and Depression and was touched by the relationships and strength Elsa developed,  with Hannah’s talents, I think she could have written a less depressing and more tightly written story.

author: Karen
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2021
review_content: When I got about a quarter of the way through this book, I almost stopped. There are multiple disappointments, hardships, heartbreaks. If you are starting to read the book,  prepare yourself.  I persevered. And I was rewarded by the celebration of human nature, the heroic and selfless characters and the demonstration of community that ensued. I will not romanticize it; it is a difficult read. But it is one of those books that transcends ordinary novels in its theme and purpose. Don't give up. Read it. You won't be sorry.
title: Not an easy book to read

author: Toni
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2021
review_content: Such a great book! I will say that I was not sure that I wanted to read it when I first read the synopsis on Amazon but all the positive reviews then the recommendation of a friend convinced me to go head.I am so glad that I did. What a story! Ms  Hannah made you feel like you were right there through all the hard times with all the characters. Character and location discs were so believeable. So much emotion in one story.Please if you don't read another book this year, read The Four Winds. You won't regret it !
title: Amazing

author: Donna D
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2021
review_content: If you don't read another book this year, read this one!  It is one of those books you can't stop reading but you don't want it to end.There is the indomitable spirit of life in the people you meet, in this woman  who kind of stumbled into her future, one she could not have imagined.This book takes place in the twenties and thirties of the twentieth century.  The woman we get to know has no idea how strong she is or the future that awaits her.Unfortunately I can see some of the ugliness directed toward immigrants happening today as it did one hundred years ago.I am so glad I found this book. It wss waiting for me. I will recommend it to everyone I know and everyone I don't know.Now I am going to enjoy my day eating three meals  and having a nice warm bed to sleep in tonight.
title: Wow! Powerful!

author: Kathy R. Bergevin
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 27, 2021

author: Kat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2021
review_content: This is my first and last book by this author.  Political statements are not necessary when reading a book. Repetitive-how many repetitions of blowing tumbleweeds, dust and wind. I'm surprised anyone would publish this pro-communist dribble.  Relieved when I finished it.
title: Disappointed

author: Lauren Peterson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2021
review_content: Stop what you’re doing and go get this book. Kristin Hannah’s “The Four Winds” is easily my favorite read so far this year. If you want an emotionally gripping page-turner with an incredible female protagonist, then this is your book—and if you enjoy historical fiction, even better. The story follows Elsa and her struggles as a mother during the Great Depression and Dust Bowl of the 30’s. The hardships she endures are beyond comprehension and she is soon faced with the decision to set out west and leave the land she loves or stay behind and hope things get better. The decision is soon made for her when one of her children almost dies after a storm. This book is a gentle reminder of the true hardships people faced during that generation—hardships that make our current situation look painless. If you are looking for feel good fluff, this isn’t for you. And to write a book with these circumstances being anything but gut-wrenching would be a disservice to the people who survived these times. A must read for your 2021 year.
title: My Favorite Read so Far This Year!!!

author: Barbara A. Stewart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2021
review_content: I do not know what book that some of the reviews read in condemning this book as to political or to depressing.  It is obvious that these readers know nothing of history or of a world that my grandparents and my mother and father grew up in to survive and then to become known as the greatest generation.  Every reader should read this book not only for a great story but for the historical perspective.  I grew up on these stories of how hard my grandparents worked to put food on the table.  How my grandmother cried when the family cow died because of now enough food to eat.  We baby boomers for most part did not grow up with silver spoons in our mouths but we grew up with parents we did know what it was to survive and to sacrifice to try to provide for us a better world by remembering where they came from then  but to go on and win World War II. They  wanted to give their children a better world.  I don’t want to live in a communist or fascist world, so read to learn, read to understand, read to be a better person and this book and “The Grapes of Wrath” would be a great place to start.
title: Stunning.  A must read!!

author: C. Dunn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2021
review_content: I started it and I’m putting it away. I like my happy life to read this dark hole of a book with with misery. I can tell it’s a page turner but goodness on all of Amazon there have to be better options.
title: Hell no

author: L. Samuels
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2021
review_content: This book was so, so good 😄. At the same time, it was so, so sad 😭! Going into it, I knew it would tug at my heartstrings for three reasons—it’s about the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl in Texas, Hannah’s books ALWAYS make me emotional, and I read a few reviews.The Four Winds reads like a saga with a mood of resilience, the struggle to survive during endless tragedies, and frustration over the desire for things to get better. Hannah is an expert at writing about relationships. In this book, the female relationships resounded for me. There was so much love and strength between: Elsa and Rose, Elsa and Jean, and Elsa and Loreda. The courage of a mother with unyielding love for her children was beautiful as well.Although fiction, The Four Winds is written with such realism that it provides an informative story about this period in US history—depicting issues of class struggle, prejudice, poverty, migration, and messages on what it means to be American. In some ways it reminded me of The Grapes of Wrath, a book I would also recommend reading.
title: One of my favorites (so far) of 2021

author: Tucker Lynn
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2021
review_content: First off I’m a huge fan of Kristen Hannah, she has an amazing gift to weave her characters into such realistic believable and heart wrenching tales. And her creation of family bonds and backstory is probably my very favorite part about her writing. I have loved most all of her books but this one fell flat for me in so many ways. First the ending of this book, without spoiling it, it honestly felt like it was rushed. She spent so much time developing this story so deeply and then the last 2 chapters just felt incredibly sped through. Also, while most can appreciate listening to other’s opinions on politics and don’t mind opposing views, I wasn’t expecting or wanting to read over and over again about politics at all. I read fiction as a mental break from the crazy world we live in, I know others feel the same. Lastly the tone of the story was incredibly disappointing. I feel like Hannah greatly missed an opportunity, in her choice to write historical fiction, to show the great ability of humans to overcome adversity. If she had dug deeper and maybe spent some time in person in the Central Valley instead of just reading about it in books, I think she would have found many stories of families who migrated during the dust bowl and while they faced extreme hardships came out to actually be very successful and even very wealthy families in the generations that followed. Many as very successful farmers and business owners. As someone who has lived and worked in the California AG community in the Central Valley, I can tell you if you take the time to talk to some farmers and ranchers you will find many with very amazing family history rich with hardship, perseverance and success. THAT kind of a story is something we could have all used to inspire right now and is actually more realistic than the tale that was weaved. I wish Hannah had showed us a family like that, instead of one who fled back to the south and blamed the government for all their problems.
title: Miss the old Kristen Hannah books

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2021
review_content: I was turned off by the commercial for Communism!  This is the second book I have read by this author, and I just do not get the hype.  The Grapes of Wrath so much better writing, character development, story telling.
title: Don't read...read Grapes of Wrath instead.

author: Gale
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2021
review_content: My grandparents and parents lived through the Depression so I've heard many accounts about what it took to survive.  The one thing my dad said, just recently, was at least "we didn't have to worry about dust storms and our land blowing away. We were able to plant enough and put up enough to feed ourselves."  Growing up, we farmed that land, and still have it so I understand the connection to the land that they speak of. Although my mom, being an only child, didn't have things as difficult, her mother's father walked out on the family just as Rafe did, never to be seen or heard from again, leaving my great grandmother with 5 children to raise and support.  Historical fiction almost always a worthwhile read.  The book is well researched and a good representation of the times.
title: Loved this book

author: ace ares Laxamana
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2021
review_content: This is a hard hitting historical fiction book. This is the third Kristin Hannah book I have read, and this is was not my favorite one. I really enjoyed this book a lot, and it was very well written like all the other Kristin Hannah books. Kristin Hannah books are not for the light hearted because they are hard hitting and goes into the dark parts of the subject the book is covering. This one takes place during the great depression it starts in Texas. I have to say the characters are well developed, but they are strong hearted women that does not takes crap. I loved the characters. This book made me call my Grandmother who is the strongest women I know, and she was born in 1935. I loved books that makes me really think, and I also love when they show us how much the world as changed. I was kindly provided an e-copy of this book by the publisher (St. Martin's Press) or author (Kristin Hannah) via NetGalley, so I can give honest review about how I feel about this book. I want to send a big Thank you to them for that.
title: Another Great Women's Power Stories

author: Jannetta
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2021
review_content: I really enjoyed this book despite the sadness in it. In the end, it's a story of survival and heroism in the face of extreme adversity. It's good historical fiction and is helpful in understanding what people went through during that period in that part of the country and as they migrated west.  And I will say I take exception with the reviewer that said this was only written to promote communism. Good grief. I guess the new deal and fighting for more than a pittance after working an entire day in the harshest of conditions while your employer  keeps you in debt, is considered communism by that reviewer. I would not let her review influence you unless you share that feeling.
title: Well written and informative

author: Aquakeke
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2021
review_content: My Kindle said I was 95% into this book and still the story hadn’t turned around.  Depressing and grim story about the Dust Bowl and the Great Depression.  Just when you think it couldn’t get worse for this family, it’s does!  I know these were sad times, but come on!  Hundreds of pages of poverty and misery with no relief.  SPOILER ALERT! author: Jan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2021
review_content: Got political 3/4 of the way through and turned me off.  I will not recommend this Kristin Hannah book nor will I share it.  I am sorry I purchased it.
title: Did not like!

author: Ari
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2021
review_content: Great writing, very lacking edition. Editors are suppose to make certain cuts, additions, etc. This editor didn't  do his/her job. This book is soooooo repetitive! There are entire scenes that one reads two or three times. How many times are we going to read about sand storms with the same outcome!? After reading about two of them, when the third one comes,  we could believe that something beyond what happened on the first or second one will happen....but, no....the same! How many times do I have to read about how the morning starts on the farm, about skinny horses or dogs on the road, about the road from the farm to the town. About the relationship with the women in the story  (beautiful characters). The writing is wonderful; the author knows how to paint the scenes, there is no need to repeat  them so many times. Cut about 100 (or more) pages from this book and I give it 5+ stars. What a shame about the editor.
title: Great writing. Bad editor.

author: Barbara D. Leachman
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2021
review_content: I read some reviews of this book by people who said the author was pushing communism. This is a well written history of the dust bowl days and the people who survived. Yes, some of the people who escaped to California were recruited by the communists. The reason? Because they were being taken advantage of: low wages, hard work with little care of their welfare, hated by CA residents. Did some of them believe the communists? Yes. They had little choice because the wealthy landowners could use them for very little money and make them only use their money in their stores, which charged higher prices than in a town store. The author was writing a fictional account of historical truths. And she wrote it well.
title: Not communist at all

author: Susan D. Blas
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2021
review_content: Loved and hated this book! Loved because it was well written as Hannah’s books are.  And because it enlightened me about a time in US history I knew very little about.  The Dust Bowl years were horrible and devastating to our country.  I hated this book because it was one catastrophe after another! Almost no joy or anything to be happy about.  Page after page of tragedy.  Jus when you think something good has to happen....Bam...another disaster!  Dust storms.  Drought.  Loss of crops. Floods. Sickness. Death. Starvation. No shelter. And a bit of Communism thrown in for good measure.  Good Grief! I kept thinking when is this going to end?
title: So much heartache and suffering

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2021
review_content: Maybe this wasn't a good book to read during a pandemic. I thought it was more depressing than Laura Ingalls Wilder's The Long Winter! And The Dirty Thirties lasted more than just one season. I did enjoy the characters, particularly the daughter Loreda who was fourteen when the storyline finally seemed to get moving. Unfortunately, the book was nearly 75% done by then. If I were making a movie of this book, I would tell the back story in flashbacks rather than a linear past to present.

author: mlv-cincy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2021
review_content: As I was reading this book, I was amazed at how little I knew about the Dust Bowl and the fight for fair wages for the farm workers. I loved learning some of this history. This has inspired me to read further into this topic. That being said, I found the storyline to be very predictable, the characters were very two dimensional and often melodramatic!  If you want to know more about the above topics, there has got to be a better written novel out there.
