author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2021
review_content: This book took longer to finish than usual because I had to stop reading to cry. The sadness would sometimes overwhelm me as the crisis in America today, in 2021 is happening to so many and the same situation of rich getting richer while poor suffer is so horrible. When life is so hard it threatens to kill you and when young people are crossing a border after walking for miles to escape a life that may kill them there are billionaires who call them names and think they are happy to live  on handouts. It’s frightening to me and few are brave enough to stand up and fight like Elsa. The one thing I wish I knew was what happened to Rafe. Totally recommend that you read this story and learn our history from the Great Depression.
title: Heartbreaking story of real life

author: Nico0157
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2021
review_content: I almost called in sick to work to stay home and finish this book.Hannah is a powerful writer who creates an intense fascination for history and the human spirit.I cried when I finished this book.Sad tears and happy tears.
title: You'll cry

author: love books
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2021
review_content: This is a wonderful book, so well written.  A woman struggles to have an identity and becomes involved with a man who disappoints her.  Elsa, a mother, wife and daughter in law), shows her love to her family by her selflessness.  They live in Texas during the Great Dust Bowl and depression of the 30's.  Her husbands leaves in the middle of the night and she is left to provide for her children and in-laws.  The story takes you from Texas to California and her struggles to provide food and shelter for her children as a migrant worker.  Wonderfully written and full of emotion, drama and love.  Excellent for a book club discussion.  Lots of comparison to the migrants coming to America today.
title: History and Love of a Mother

author: JM
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2021
review_content: I had to stop reading, it was so boring. I read a lot and I have read a few really great dust bowl novels that I thought were amazing. Yes, depressing as it was an awful time but I was engaged. I have read a few of her books and  the reviews were so overwhelmingly five stars. I wasted money on this one. I didn't care for any of the characters. No depth and some of the writing was hokey sounding. Very disappointed and I didn't finish it. My time is too valuable to keep reading when I was not engaged.
title: Boring

author: Lee Schwartzberg
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2021
review_content: First, I think it's hilarious that people gave it one star because of the political content... these, I'm sure, are the same folks who have a problem with raising the minimum wage to a (barely) living wage. I mean, because why should someone work 80 hours a week at $7.25 ($30,000 a year) and complain about it... amiright????Anyway... to the book. Gosh. I so wanted things to turn out well for this incredibly resilient and hard-working family, but it seems like things went from bad to worse, to absolutely dire.It's a page turner for sure, but it left me completely drained. The last few pages gave us some hope, but not enough, imho, to offset the utter horror of the other 99% of the book.For purely literary reasons, I much prefer Steinbeck's The Grapes of Wrath. Hannah writes almost like she's in a rush, and I guess she is, considering how many books she pumps out. I wish she would slow it down, take her time, and maybe spend a few more moments to craft her sentences.Good read, good story.
title: Left me gutted

author: Marcia Grubbs-Weiss
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2021
review_content: I don’t often write reviews, however after reading this book I am compelled to. This book is one of the BEST I have ever read. I could not put it down. While some reviewers have said this book is political, I would say that often being human is political. The book has extremely well developed characters who are coming into an understanding of who the are. The issues of the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl help them hone and define their own characters as a result of having to survive during this challenging period.  This book makes you think and question, as well as being extremely relevant to today’s issues. Above all, this book is about love, learning to give it and to receive it.
title: Powerful moving read

author: Raymond Speltz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 22, 2021
review_content: The first half of the book was great, but the last half was dumb. It promotes communism and left too many unanswered questions. I love books on the Depression era, but this was a disappointment
title: Disappointed

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2021
review_content: I was very disappointed in this book. After finished Nightingale I was looking forward to another great story.  The first half was wonderful. The second half promotes communism and is very depressing. I felt as if Kristen didn’t know where to go once she opened that subject matter.
title: Don’t buy unless you want to be depressed.

author: Gila
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 3, 2021
review_content: I have read two other books by Kristin Hannah and was hoping to like this one, too.This book takes you through a saga of unbelievable struggles and heart ship. The writing is so powerful that I could see, feel and taste what was happening to these people. Even though you read about the dust storms several times, it felt like each incident was happening with its own characteristic battle; the writing was fresh and responsive to each new situation.I am in two book clubs and both book clubs have liked this selection. I think that it is a well crafted story that shows human spirit that pushes ahead and fights to overcome the worst hardships imaginable.I felt very connected to the story and would highly recommend reading this book of historical fiction.
title: A book that stays with you

author: Amy Hammond Hagberg
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2021
review_content: Kristin Hannah is arguably the reigning rock star of historical fiction. The Nightingale is currently in movie production at TriStar Pictures, which also optioned her novel, The Great Alone. One thing I like most about her writing is her pacing. Historical fiction can be tedious, but she does a wonderful job of keeping the plot moving. Her character descriptions help readers see them, but I didn’t feel like I got to know Elsa’s heart. The point of view and pronouns were confusing: sometimes Mom, sometimes Elsa, sometimes Grandma and sometimes Rose. Consistency would have been better in that regard. Although The Four Winds wasn’t my favorite of her books, it was still excellent. 4 stars
title: An interesting period in American history

author: Judy Hendrickson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2021
review_content: Much of this book was difficult for me to read. I struggled with the knowledge that many migrant workers still live in similar conditions. Many homeless Americans still struggle today to stay alive. When you have lost everything it is difficult to get clean and beautiful to go to a job interview. It’s difficult to even find somewhere to use the restroom when you’re homeless. It’s so sad that we’re really not a lot better off today than we were during the depression. This book is so well written and ultimately, it was enjoyable to read. I just had to take little bits at a time to keep my heart from breaking. Like all Kristin Hannah books, the story is touching.
title: The Four Winds

author: English teacher lady
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2021
review_content: Thought provoking text that will keep me pondering for weeks. I am a retired English teacher, but if I was still teaching, I would definitely have my students compare this novel with Of Mice and Men. Contrary to what some reviewers have stated, this is not a book about Communism, but about American history, told from a female perspective.  My favorite quotation in the the book comes not from the novel proper, but from the “Author’s Note.”  Hannah states: “In the end it is our idealism and our courage and our commitment to one another—what we have in common—that will save us” (449). If that isn’t a statement about what needs to happen in the United States, I don’t know what is.
title: Definitely worth reading

author: Chris Maston
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2021
review_content: I know the times were very hard with the dust bowl and the conditions of farming in California but I read to relax as well as learning historical information in historical fiction. This book was depressing from cover to cover.  The characterization was good, but I found it hard to read because the days in Texas were the same all the time and it kept repeating how bad it was. I think the story could have been a lot shorter because it dragged in many places.
title: Very depressing book

author: CJ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2021
review_content: I purchased this on my kindle for my book club. I realize that the Great Depression was a horrible experience and it is not my intention to discount it’s hardships. (I remember hearing stories from mother when she was a young girl.) However, I grew up in an abusive home and experienced oppression and favoritism so I had to stop reading the book. I found it depressing. There are those things in life that you experience and find that they are in no way entertaining to read in a book or watch on the screen.
title: Too Close To Home For Me To Read

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021
review_content: Brilliant novel that takes place during the dust bowl and the Great Depression.  Strong female character, Elsa, alternates narrating with her daughter.  Four stars instead of five, because the ending didn't flow organically.  The last two chapters and epilogue seem forced.  I also truly did not like the daughter.  Other reviews say she's a strong female character, I thought she was a spoiled rotten brat- which didn't fit with the circumstances in which she lived.  I've read other reviews that complain that it's "too political" and "too sad"... it's HISTORY based on the Great DEPRESSION (guess lots of people need to re-take American History class).
title: Outstanding HISTORICAL fiction

author: Kimbee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 22, 2021
review_content: Why do I rate a book so full of pain a five out of five stars?  Because this one made me both think and feel shame about the way we treat other people who aren't the same as us.  Though the characters are fictional, the heartbreaking events are history.  It's also a story about the indomitable spirit of people who live through tragedy, coming away stronger from their experiences....and how love triumphs over all.
title: Devastating Honesty

author: Liz
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2021
review_content: If John Steinbeck had not stolen Sonora Babb's research for her book Whose Names Are Unknown, I am sure she would have asked Hanna to co-write or ghost write the Dust Bowl contents that she researched. Hannah is SUPERB in her ability to bring the greatest man made disaster this country has ever seen to life. The Dust Bowl is rarely taught in schools and should be a focal point on everything from migration from the midwest to west to abuse of migrant workers by big money. She even mentions the Roosevelts' plan to change the way farmers plant their crops in the midwest to avoid days-on-end dust storms that landed dirt all the way to Washington D.C. It's Kristin Hannah at her best!
title: Kristin Hanna's research of Sonora Babb impeccable

author: Good Read
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021
review_content: Having never read “The Grapes of Wrath”, I found this historical novel about the Depression Era and the Dust Bowl very interesting and enlightening. I think there are many parallels to events and society from those times that are relevant in today’s world. I think the criticism that this novel is promoting communism or any political statement is unfair. I believe Hannah researched the times of the day and wrote about what was happening from the perspective of those suffering through the times of that day. Her work is insightful and is a powerful observation on the good and not so good in the history of the United States and the heroism that brought change to this country for the good of humanity. That being said, the book is not a light, happy read and you may need a box of tissues.
title: Poignant and compelling historical novel

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2021
review_content: I have read several of this author's books, and was very excited to pre-order this one several month ago. Must say I am disappointed. I found the writing to be on high school level, and many times jumping around with no transition. I kept reading thinking there would be a wow factor change in the narrative going forward, but it was more and more depressing as it went on. Often felt contrived to push the communistic union movement forward. Maybe I was expecting a John Steinbeck Grapes of Wrath page turner, but Four Winds fell short.
title: Disappointment from a Favorite Author

author: Alan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2021
review_content: Thought I'd try something different from my history-crime-thriller genres but after a few pages it dawned on me...people don't  talk to each other this way...I read just the dialogue after that and it felt like an elementary school primer...I tried...oh well...didn't get past page 5...unreadable...and I don't  like to leave bad reviews but felt compelled
title: Childish Dialogue

author: Michelle D.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 28, 2021
review_content: I'm a huge fan of this author and inhaled books like The Nightingale and The Great Alone - call me basic but I loved them.  I was so excited to read this one based on the reviews but it fell short for me.  Upon reading the first third of the book I had a hard time connecting with the characters and getting invested in the story.  I can't quite put a finger on why but I didn't find myself wanting to read more, know more as I have with her other books.  I think maybe (and I'm no author) that she leapt straight into the story and didn't spend enough time developing a backstory to connect you emotionally with the heroine and didn't thread their stories throughout as she does with her other books.The middle of the book was better for me but the last third was just me turning page after page as quickly as possible.  Normally I would have just put it down (it took me 10+ years post college to realize you can just stop reading a book if you're not into it - lol) but I was reading it for book club so I wanted to see it through.  I see other reviewers complaining of it being a political statement - and it is to a certain extent, and I admit it does make you think about your lot in life and how lucky some have it versus others.  And what people in this country have gone through and continue to go through.  But more than anything the story just rang false to me.  It was too contrived, the heroines fate in the end just felt wrong and less for the story and more for the message.  I have no issue reading books on all sides of many issues, whether they align with my personal beliefs or not, however this one just felt so forced to me.I still gave it three stars as I enjoyed (that word feels wrong but that's what I read for - enjoyment) reading about their time living through the horrors of the dust bowl and the prejudice and shame they encountered upon arriving in California.  I didn't love it but I didn't hate it either.  I rarely write reviews but this book just had so much hype I felt the urge to do so when it came up (yet again) in my suggestions.
title: I've Loved Other Kristin Hannah Books More...

author: B Kelly
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2021
review_content: While I suppose it was fairly well researched, this book was sad, depressing, and repetitive.  I'm mad that I invested time and money on this book.
title: Depressing and sad

author: Kasey
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2021
review_content: This book leaves me with a greater appreciation for the hardships I previous generation faced that built the prosperity and privileges that we enjoy in modern America. I take for granted the rights that I have as a citizen, employee, and woman. It was both painful and a joy to be able to immerse myself in the hardships and struggle a faced during the Great Depression era and Dust Bowl and quite interesting to learn about the challenges brought on by the great migration to California. I love an enthralling work of fiction that also teaches lessons about history and changes our perspective on the world we live in.
title: Submersive historical fiction

author: melissa e. six
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
review_content: The book starts out great, really catches your attention. Then chapters 7-25 completely ruin the entire book. It's just, dust, storm, people leaving, sadness, dust storm, people leaving, sadness...... with absolutely nothing new added to the story line, then right near the end of the book it actually catches your attention again & then the books over with no closure for 1 of the main characters.  Like what happens to him????? The end. Kinda regret spending $17 on this book.
title: Nothing to keep your attention. Boring.

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2021
review_content: I have read all of the author’s books and have loved each one of them. Our book club read The Nightingale and I have recommended The Great Alone many times. The Four Winds was written about a depressing topic and it was a depressing book. I read The Grapes of Wrath and cried as I read it. I felt no emotion as I read this book not even when characters died. This book is not one I will recommend. So disappointed.
title: Not my Favorite Kristin Hannah book

author: Deborah A. G
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2021
review_content: I disliked the simplicity of the characters at the beginning and the lack of depth in the writing. I felt as if it was a telling not a showing and I wanted to just find out why everyone loved it. As it progressed, Elsa and Lorena were developed and the book grabbed my attention. This would be a readable book for middle school students who want to know more about the Dust Bowl.
title: Readable

author: lynee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2021
review_content: Riveting. I couldn't  put it down.  The story and characters came alive on the page. The story of the bravery of the people in the Dust Bowl was astounding. I fell in love with Elsa and her children. A and the grand parents.Their flight west and the struggles they encountered were mesmerizing.  I never knew of the unfairness and treatment they lived with. The danger was so real. Jack stands out as truth in the midst of chaos and  cruelty.The brief romance he and Elsa shared  was a spark of happiness in her bleak life.The courage and fire inside of Loreda made her aR
title: Elsa

author: brennie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2021
review_content: I've read most, if not all, of Kristin Hannah's novels. This was probably my least favorite. There were far, far too many pages saying the same thing, in different words, over and over. We get it, times were hard.  I felt like at least a fourth of the book was repetitive, if not closer to half. I have noticed many reviewers mentioning that this book seems to be pro communism/socialist. I did not get that as a takeaway at all. Pro Union, yes. Though I'm far from pro-union in this day and age, there was a time and a place in history where they were needed and this was one of those times in US history.
title: Slow, Not the Author's Best but still worth reading

author: Denise K. Maguire
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2021
review_content: I have very mixed feelings about this book. It’s an important story because it’s an important part of America’s history. But did it need to be so gruesome?  So devastatingly depressing?  It reminded me of stories from the concentration camps in WWII, almost intolerable in its description of a miserable day-to-day existence hardly better than death. On the positive side, like all of the books by this author, there is a compelling story, well written, with wonderful characters and flawless writing. I just wish Kristen Hannah took her foot off the pain and suffering pedal once in a while.
title: A Heart-wrenching Book

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2021
review_content: From page one the characters in this book became real people to me. They will live in my head and my heart forever as will the gut wrenching story of the dust bowl, the depression and the resilience of a few courageous people. It’s often difficult to find role models these days but this book is full of them, even if the characters are fictional.  These “heroes” were not born with the conviction and courage they displayed but grew into it over a lifetime. Their struggles were real and the author beautifully captured the development of each character with words and a story that touched me deeply.
title: Excellent read. Educational and emotional.

author: Thomas E. Botts
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2021
review_content: Many seem to dislike this novel because it is depressing or they think it advocates communism.  I am not sure I would have expected anything other than depressing given the historic period it portrays.  I also do not see it as advocating communism.  Rather the book portrays how things were during the depression for the "Okies" and their oppression in California in the early 1930s.The book is well written.  It is depressing, yes, but like the "Grapes or Wrath", it tells an important story about how it was for so many Americans who were victims  of a depression, a drought, the dust storms, then victims of oppression when they moved to California trying to find work.I enjoyed this book because it was well written and seemed to be a well researched book on a very difficult time in American history.
title: Very well written historical novel

author: Anne Sweeney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2021
review_content: This wasn’t a happy read. It is a hard read but gripping. You shake your head a lot wondering how people can lack compassion but then KH throws an act of kindness just when you give up hope. She tries to give her characters growth and champions the womens voice. This is about so many things but it is about strong women and their tenacity to survive in the hardest and most awful of times.  In this world where we have seen so much division this novel reminds us that love is what matters and compassion for our fellow human a must. We miss out when we stand divided. Excellent read.
title: Another brilliant KH novel

author: P. York
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2021
review_content: I know some will disagree but I feel this is a very depressing book which promoted communism.  Yes, I know it was a very depressing time in our country’s history and she captured it well. Kristin Hannah is one of my favorite authors and I look forward to her next book. This one was just not an enjoyable read for me.
title: Disappointed

author: almostfrench0612
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2021
review_content: First, I am a huge Kristin Hannah fan. I loved especially winter garden and Night road, as well as firefly lane. I felt with this one (as with the Great alone) that the story took a while to get going. It was not until about halfway through the book that I got to the “I can’t put this down” stage. The story was beautiful but I have to admit I was disappointed by the ending. I’m not going to spoil it but even with that aside I felt it was just way too rushed for this story and I didn’t think we got sufficient closure. Considering how long it took for the “mise en place” in the first half, I felt that the ending did not quite do the story justice. That being said, i would still recommend the book, hence why 4 stars.
title: Good but not great

author: sheezarater
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2021
review_content: Marxist views taint the dramatic impact of the historical fiction in this book. It was great for the first half and  then got too preachy and maudlin.
title: A Spellbinding Story Suffers From Sanctimoniousness.

author: testykat
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2021
review_content: I have enjoyed her novels for years. I rarely write reviews. This book was so darn hard to read. My Mom and Dad grew up during this era so I was familiar with some of things that took place during this time. If you want to be uplifted, do not read this book. I wanted a happy ending.
title: Depressing!

author: Lisa
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 11, 2021
review_content: I ordinarily love Kristin Hannah but this book was the worst, most depressing, book I've ever read and I've read a lot of books. Its not like Crawdads where there was hope and redemption. This was truly gut wrenchingly depressing until the last page. And I finished it because I was hoping for something hopeful and good to happen and it just didn't.
title: Don't read unless you want to slit your own wrists

author: Barbara Mitchell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2021
review_content: This book is very well written... ..But it is depressing.....I finally put it down and I will never pick it back up to finish..If you want to read this book, so be it...I will not write  a good review as the subject is too much
title: This book is Heartbreaking....

author: Sandra Fielder
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2021
review_content: Kristin Hannah writes another unforgettable story about a brave heroine.  Elsa never thought much of herself, but she made a huge impact on everyone she encountered.  She is courageous in so many ways.  She leaves the Dust Bowl because her son could die if she doesn't.  She and her young son and teenage daughter live in a camp for migrant farm workers.  They have no structure to call home.  They travel to pick whatever crop is in season. They eventually find a little more stable place to live that comes with more debt than can be overcome.  You will read this book and feel so advantaged to have a roof over your head and daily meals to eat.  Memorable and unforgettable.  Thank you, Kristin Hannah for another great book!
title: The Dust Bowl vs Migrant Workers in California

author: D. B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2021
review_content: I like realism and learning from struggles of humanity.  But this story was awful - especially having to read over and over about suffering animals, let alone people. I found myself skipping over the political, pro-communist parts that just kept coming. There's some value in understanding what suffering took place, but I really couldn't wait to end this book.
title: Depressing

author: M. Woods
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2021
review_content: The good things first.  It wasn’t obscene, it was an easy read and of historical interest. What I didn’t care for was, first of all, times are tough.  Why do I want to read a downer book? Don’t we have enough misery these days? Secondly, why portray communism as the thing that was the bright light for the characters? Nah, not for me.  This was my first and last book by this author.
title: Meh

author: Derrith E. Lambka
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2021
review_content: “There are lessons to be learned from history. Hope to be derived from hardships faced by others.” Kristin Hannah in the epilogue.Lessons yes. Not much hope in this book. I learned about the human impact to women and children and grandparents during the devastating dust bowl and then about the awful lives as American migrants in California during the depression. To survive required so much grit, tenacity and luck. Empathy-building for sure.I was captivated by the story for 3/4 of it. Then I felt it became contrived and way too sad/hard.
title: Life was very, very, very hard ...

author: Fred Reichenbach
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2021
review_content: This is my third book by Kristin Hannah and I will be ordering another. She writes with such clarity that the scenes unfold before you. And her characters and their personalities come alive!I hadn't read anything previously about the Dust Bowl. She captures the horror and pain those who lived through it must have endured. Coming from a poor family (and the first of the family to graduate college), I could relate to the worrying my parents went through when I was a child.I've been a union member, as well as a high-level executive in companies. If it were not for unions, there would be far more poverty in our nation. I carried by union "attitude" into management, always taking care of my employees.The bravery and sacrifices made by the characters in this book in California to fight for fair wages is something we need more of in today's society.
title: Excellent Book Testament to the Cruelty of Greed

author: Robert A. Hall
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2021
review_content: I thought “The Nightingale” was Hannah’s masterpiece, but I couldn’t put this novel about an American family in the depression and the dustbowl down. It is hard to believe 85+ years later that this could have happened in America. You have had an easy life, trust me. If you think otherwise read this book. Hannah is a brilliant writer. She creates characters you will care about long after you finish the last page. Her dialog, scenes and research are all terrific. I wasn’t able to put the book down until I finished it. I recommend it without reservation.
title: A wonderful novel of an American Tragedy

author: Suzanne Casamento
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 11, 2021
review_content: Last night, I finished THE FOUR WINDS. I have several observations:1. Thank God for historical fiction. Without it, I never would have learned how it might have felt to have lived through The Dust Bowl, FEVER 1793, the Salem Witch Trials, and of course, slavery.2. There is a terrifying similarity to how migrant workers were abused and terrorized in the 1930's to the way they are abused and terrorized today.That infuriates me. Why doesn't this country learn its lessons?3. What also infuriates me is that in my 16 years of education, I don't recall any of these abuses being taught in the curriculum.I love to read, so I'm always seeking out stories, but what about the people who don't read? How will they ever know history is repeating itself?
title: Harrowing and Heartbreaking

author: Claire S.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2021
review_content: Kristin Hannah has the ability to tell a good story. I appreciated the characters and reality of her latest book until the last few pages when she did her usual number of turning into a sermon with a moral. It ruined the book for me, just the same as she did in The Nightingale. A good story should tell itself; it shouldn't have a moral rammed down the reader's throat at the end.
title: Preachy as always

author: KAREN M KENNEDY
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2021
review_content: I totally agree with the other negative reviews about this book.  The book is nothing but an anti-American political statement, and a support for Socialism.  I will never read another one of Kristen Hannah's books again.
title: Very Disappointing

author: R Souter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2021
review_content: I enjoy historical fiction because I learn about times and places in history while being entertained with a story. I’m not sure entertained is the right word because there is so much that is depressing about the misery brought on by the Dust Bowl and the Great Depression in the 1930’s, but I couldn’t put this book down. By the end I was glad I persevered. It is well written with well developed characters but could have been about 100 pages shorter. The part describing the misery of the dust bowl went on far too long. There are many lessons to be learned and appreciated about the grit and courage of our ancestors who survived during this time in history.
title: Interesting Book

author: Pegster
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2021
review_content: I was so looking forward to reading Hannah’s new book but after half way through it I was getting tired of the same dreadful things happening over and over again. It was definitely a depressing book. Well written, but not a page turner.
title: So disappointing!

author: Bob Rufener
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2021
review_content: Very disappointed in Kristin Hannah. I love all her past books and she has been my favorite author. Not anymore. This book is a political statement and the pro communist agenda is a disgrace to the loyal readers who spend their money buying this book. I will never buy another one of her books. We all need an escape, we don’t need more political propaganda.
title: Very depressing book

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2021
review_content: I've read most of the author's books.  This one began to get a bit raw yet I had to know more about the Dust Bowl, the rights of farm workers in California. This is part of my past though I hadn't considered it much.In the end, though fictional, I have an added  profound respect for my grand parents and their generation. Elsa finally found her truth, her warrior spirit which we all need in today's world. Read the book, or maybe a sample...it's a great journey with inspiring characters that remind me of many I was blessed to know.
title: Harsh yet a story for these times - resilience matters.

author: Renee
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2021
review_content: This book is another multilayered story i never want to end, so I'm savoring it. Her books are the type you totally immerse yourself in, a beautiful rarity these days. Highly recommend this book, as well as The Great Alone.  Her writing style is a breath of fresh air.  I cannot recommend this book highly enough!
title: She writes extremely compelling, can't put down works of literary art!

author: Susi PultZ
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2021
review_content: Same old story about dust bowl and Califoria. Waste of money. Not reflective of authors usual work. Repetive and boring. Characters  weak.
title: Disappointing.

author: audrey wilson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2021
review_content: I really enjoyed the novel, except for the fact that my copy has repeat pages and missing pages. This is not the author’s issue but the printer’s, yet it affects the flow of the novel nonetheless. Hence, three stars.
title: Missing pages and repeat pages.

author: Sara L.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2021
review_content: I liked nothing about this book. It was a gift and I am so glad I read it before gifting it.  I was only able to read up to the last few pages where the daughter is visiting her mom's grave before leaving for college.  I stopped there and put it straight in the donation bag.  There was NO reason to write this book.  It accomplished NOTHING.  It dwells on the worst of humanity without any redeeming features.  When she finally gave her protagonist a good man, good sex and some kind of future......she killed her off!I was fooled by the good reviews and Times best seller list etc. and I am Angry!  This drivel is only for people who think they are smart and need some reason to show off.  Use your money to buy a book by an author that only wants to tell you a good story.
title: Do not fall for the hype

author: Barbara J Slatter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2021
review_content: We have been taught that there was an event in our country that was called The Dust Bowl. This book makes that time come to life.  It puts the words, experiences and life to the picture called The Migrant Mother by Dorthea Lange as well as other pictures of what those that experienced the Dust Bowl and the migration west.  That time period started so many important revaluations about agriculture, nature, workers rights and the strength of the Americans.  This book is so relevant today as well.  Look around, the reasons might be different, but have we changed that much?
title: I feel this is a time in our country that is ignored and not given how important and relevant it is today!

author: Miss Dorothy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2021
review_content: As she accomplished in her novel The Nightingale, Kristin Hannah has written strong characters and an engaging story, loosely based on the historical events of he 1930s, the Dust Bowl of the plains, the migrants pouring into the west, principally California, and the labor issues that resulted. Although I found myself cheering on Elsa and her children, I have to admit that there are many dark moments that made me give it a 4+ instead of a 5.  Overall I recommend this to historical fiction devotees and followers of Kristin Hannah.
title: Friendship, struggle and perserverance

author: Peggy T.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 6, 2021
review_content: The Four Winds held my interest from the beginning.  Remembering how awful the dust was on my first trip to West TX to meet my mother-in-law.  She remarked how they had spent the day cleaning and my thoughts were this place has not been dusted in a year.  A dust storm arrived the evening before I arrived. Not only was Four Winds a teacher about the climate but I learned a lesson about perseverance.  Another about learning to love a mother-in-law who was Italian. This book beautifully covered many life lessons and held my attention until the end.  Do read.
title: Beautifully written, a real story of love, and life.  Kept me interested.  Must read!

author: Cindy Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2021
review_content: If you know nothing about the Dust Bowl of America, or the Great Depression of the 1930's, this book will educate you.  If you had relatives who lived through the Depression of the '30s, this will be a reminder of their stories.  For me, it was a reminder of what people suffered through at that time in our country's history.  Elsinor's story is gritty and will be hard to read at times, but it is important to read it to the end.  This is what so many people in our country lived, and this story is told very beautifully.
title: Be brave.  If not, at least act like you are brave.

author: Reading For Fun
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2021
review_content: For my birthday I treated myself to the new Kristin Hannah book that I’ve been anxiously awaiting. What a disappointment. In fairness, it’s beautifully written and I’m sure it accurately depicts the stories of many hardships of the era. But it was so depressing! I admire Elsa and her courage, but I’ll think again before deciding to pay $14.99 to make myself sad.
title: DEPRESSING

author: Jenny Lynn Johnson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2021
review_content: I thought this was a fantastic fictional portrayal of a family and the struggles back in the dust bowl days. Several reviews stated it was a political statement and gave it 1 star which is absolutely thoughtless and just ridiculous, what do you think it was like back than politics played a huge part how sad that's all people got out of it, people should be ashamed of themselves. It takes great research and skill to write and this depiction of historical fiction it was heartbreaking but so very worth the read and eye opening.
title: Excellent historical fiction

author: Angela F.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 20, 2021
review_content: Kristin never fails to move my soul to feel deeply for her characters. The historical content gave me a new perspective of a time I knew little about, which of itself is a great testament. Then add the depth of characters and circumstances. I could feel the heat and the cold, taste the dust, experience the anger and desperation. The search to be loved even as one loves deeply. Would have enjoyed a different ending, but then, would it have branded me so permanently? I recommend highly to those not afraid to be stretched in their perspective, or maybe just brave enough because of that fear.
title: Transported

author: matthew madan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2021
review_content: What are we coming to as a country when people are giving this book one star because they think it's promoting Communism? It's not. Yes, there is a strike, and the organizers are Communists, but nowhere does the book present as an endorsement of an ideology. These were displaced migrants fighting to earn a livable wage.This said, I enjoyed this book and shed a tear or two at the end. No, it's not top-tier literary fiction, but Hannah does a really nice job making what could be a very very sad story hold up through 400-plus pages. Mostly, the theme is so positive and the protagonist so endearing that I could easily dismiss a little bit of pedestrian prose. Also, I genuinely didn't know how the plot was going to work out, so kudos to Hannah for that. Finally, there's a great subplot focused on mother-daughter relationships that rang very true to my mind.All in all, this is definitely a book worth reading. If you haven't read "The Grapes of Wrath," this is a modern version from which we can all learn a lot about American history, specifically about the Dust Bowl Era and the Great Migration to California. No, Hannah isn't Steinbeck, but not many writers are. Well done.
title: Solid Historical Fiction

author: Sue
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2021
review_content: Kristin Hannah is my favorite author!  The Four Winds was another well-written and obviously researched book.  The heroine, Elsa Martinelli, makes her sad marital life into something that brings her happiness.  It just seemed like tragedy after tragedy, and I kept waiting for life to cut her a break.  While I love, love, loved, the book, the trials of this family were definately depressing!
title: Well Written!

author: Nettie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2021
review_content: This book resonated with me beginning with Elsa having Rheumatic Fever.  I had it at ages nine, eleven and eighteen, and, like Elsa, it colored the rest of my life.  I had no health insurance because of it as it was considered a preexisting condition.  It was not until age twenty when I became a federal employee that I finally had health care.  Women were treated like second  class citizens pretty much in every facet of life, as were those who were poverty stricken.  Nothing much has changed, and it is still a world where those who have the least are considered "less than".  This book brought back the sadness and anger I have felt throughout my life over the inequities that exist in the society we live in.  It was painful to read and realize that not a lot has changed after all these years.  It is affecting on so many levels.  Wonderful read.
title: Powerful

author: Helaine Mario
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2021
review_content: I loved this book.  It’s a huge, epic, sprawling story that brought America in the 1930s to life for me – the Texas dustbowl, the Depression, the bone-crushing poverty and migrant issues in California – a portrait of America that is as timely and heart-breaking as today’s news.  Sometimes brutally raw, but always honest.  For me, the heart of this beautifully told and deeply felt story is Elsa – it’s about one woman’s indomitable strength to take care of her children under impossible challenges, about a woman who somehow finds the courage to stand on her own, follow her heart, and go on.
title: one indomitable woman's story

author: randy varney
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021
review_content: I was drawn into the story of Elsa who as a child was tossed aside because of lack of beauty , but in the end is a heroine who displays courage even when she had to pretend. It's a story of the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl and the tremendous pain and heartbreak suffered by those whose lives were forever broken , but not diminished .This beautifully written narrative will have you feel the heat, taste the powdery dirt , and live the pain of a mother whose love is limitless even when her courage isn't. Read this story and be changed giving hope at a time we all need it. The plot twists and turns and keeps you guessing, but in the end the heroine's transformation will leave you breathless. I feel that I am a better person for reading this masterfully written prose. Wow!
title: Kristin Hannah's Triumph of Historical Narrative

author: Debbie Patten
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2021
review_content: I was disappointed in this book. Yes, Kristin Hannah takes us through the remarkable journey of survival during one of the darkest times in American history. But, it just wasn't an enjoyable read. Of course the topic is depressing so not the right choice for a book to lose myself in. I didn't have that "ah" moment at the end.
title: Not my favorite

author: larry m shrier
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2021
review_content: A Timely and well written book ; as our world moves on....everyday driving past the homeless and the suffering.....on our ways to work, store or home..seemingly too great of needs to ever right....The book takes place during the Great Depression . It is a story of Hope and courage that people can stand for justice and equality...and make a difference .... the stories of woman discovering their voice and their power to love in the face of great loss....men and woman who dare live their lives fully....
title: A story of Courage

author: Betty Jo Wilkinson
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2021
review_content: Four Winds was one of the most moving books I’ve read lately.  I would have liked to have stopped reading many times because of the gravity of the descriptions the characters experienced over and over.  When reading one  of the hospital scenes when service was refused because of the status of an “ Oakie,” I was in a doctor’s office and wanted to get up and yell against the injustices that this scene depicted and that are repeated in our country all to often in various forms.  There were many spiritual and social lessons to be garnered from this book.  Indeed, the first were last and the last were first in character if not in wealth and status.  I’m so glad I didn’t give up reading.
title: We have a long way to go to fulfill the commandment to love our neighbor.

author: Love Labs
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 25, 2021
review_content: Kristin Hannah tackles tough historical times. Times society wants to forget. You will shed tears.This is a novel about a very rough time in our country’s history. Living in Texas for many years now, with my house with central heat and air and electricity and running water and a bed and plenty of food - I cannot even begin to imagine enduring what life was like in the dust bowl years.I love Elsa and her indomitable spirit - the warrior she became. And I so identified with “Books had always been her solace; novels gave her the space to be bold, brave, beautiful, if only in her own imagination.”That’s what books, especially great books like this one, are to me.
title: Be Bold, Be Brave

author: Kindle Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2021
review_content: Kristin Hannah has done a wonderful job of creating a story about the 1930's great depression and with that she has brought to life a fictional character named Elsa and her two children. Deserted by her husband and left to teach and raise her daughter and son. The hardships a single women had to endure during depression times was very hard. It took a strong person with courage, you might even call her a warrior. This was a great journey. This was a hard book to put down at night to sleep. Excellent read.
title: The Four Winds

author: pfred4peace
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2021
review_content: I watched a documentary on the dust bowl but visualized it so much more reading this book. Yes, “Four Winds” reflected anti-big farm sentiments and labor and social welfare support.  Supporting small family farms and providing a safety net for Americans is not communism but rather speaks to the spirit of American values. Love and support thy neighbor. I hope we never see such dire conditions again, but if we do I hope that we do better. Let’s start by treating illegal immigrants humanely.
title: A peek into depression era lives

author: Katelynn Daniells
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2021
review_content: I’m a huge fan of Kristin Hannah. I’ve read every book. To say I was disappointed is disappointing. With ever page, with every chapter I kept telling myself it would come together to blow me away. Never happened. I found the story slow, the plot boring, and has me wondering if this author is tapped out with spinning amazing stories. Learned some American history and have a better understanding of the treatment of immigrants then and today and that is why this book is even getting 3 stars, I feel generous with 3.
title: Bummer, long wait for a flop!

author: BP
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2021
review_content: Without giving anything away- you will be sad and then believe it or not sadder but you will be so invested in these characters that you will find any opportunity to read " just a few more" pages. Then your sadness will turn to tears and the Kleenex will pile up and the unexpected ending will make you so happy that you read this book!  But have the Kleenex ready!!!!! These characters will stick with me for awhile.  Kristin Hannah how you keep writing these amazing books is beyond me, you are a treasure!
title: Excellent!!!!  Five PLUS

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2021
review_content: She does it again. Kristin Hannah, by far my favorite author of all time, has released another five-star, fantastic book. I loved how this was a historical story, more so like The Nightengale, and what a time in history to release such a story. Almost a century between now and then, but many similarities in how the country was struggling in multiple aspects. This story takes place during the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl that plagued the South, which I found super interesting and really didn’t know much about prior to this book. The push to leave the South, travel to Cali to look for better opportunities and a better life for your family. What horrors awaited them in California. Fighting for fair wages, similar to the fight for a higher minimum wage that is occurring now. Disease plaguing whole families. Inability to thrive as a whole. The fictional lead character Elsa was so easy to connect with and instantly love, which for me really made the book. I’m sad this one is over, but it certainly will stick with me for a long time. ❤️
title: Blown away

author: Ginger Russell
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2021
review_content: I look forward to all of Kristin Hannah's books with great anticipation, and I was not disappointed by this one.  Those of us who were born after the great depression and the dust bowl really don't have any idea how difficult this time was.  One thing that is clear in this book is the repetitive day in day out life on a midwestern farm in the 1930's.  Another is the resilience of the folks who lived through the need and starvation and eventually came out the other side.  I truly could not put this book down.
title: Dust Bowl

author: Kathi Stingle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2021
review_content: While I have enjoyed other works by this author, (including The Nightingale--one of my favorites) this was definitely the most depressing book I've ever read.  I'm certain it was well researched and probably even well written, but it went from sad to desperate. even more desperate to tragic and finally regret. As I was getting closer to finishing, I kept anticipating something uplifting--never happened.  And reading this in the year of Covid made it even worse.  I will think long and hard before reading this author again.
title: Very depressing

author: Nina Frankle
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2021
review_content: I waded in and found naught but dust and despair, chapter after chapter, and I thought this is like an American version of  "Angela's Ashes."  We have had cold, rainy winter here in Georgia with so little Sun that even  the usually hardy pansies were colorless.  Plus I was feeling fatigued after my second Covid  vaccine shot and thought why am I slogging through such a sad tale.  Yet I plowed on and welcomed the movement west. The struggles continued, more characters appeared, the action picked up, hope again appeared on the horizon, tensions soared and climaxed in a triumph with an unexpected reward of understanding and appreciation of what America suffered during the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl . Era.  The Epilogue was the perfect Bow atop the package.
title: A Full Circle Read

author: Miss Julianna
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2021
review_content: I love historical fiction though not usually drawn to time of the Great Depression. I’ve just felt like I heard so many spoken stories from a first hand family source.That said, I’m happy I picked up this title, the first I’ve read from Kristin Hannah, and not the last.The social disparities are the same today as they were in the 1930’s, so there’s much to learn about oneself imagining the hard, gritty experiences of past Americans and migrants who paved the way for today’s workers’ and family rights.I thank Kristin for helping me experience the past and appreciate the present more, through her world and characters.
title: Touching, difficult, a relevant story for contemporary generations

author: oldest city USA
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2021
review_content: Kristin Hannah is a great writer but I found the book so sad and depressing. The Dust Bowl was a horrific time  in American history and with so many unjust cruelness towards the Americans whom had to flee with next to nothing just to survive.I am sure their are those whom will disagree with meBut I just couldn’t find any joy in the book
title: Too Depressing

author: Mary Perkins
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 15, 2021
review_content: This is a powerful story. I do understand why the California people were afraid of the thousands crossing their border daily but that does not excuse their behavior. This is a shame for California and the nation. Because we are human our history, the times that came before us, are filled with mistakes reviewed in todays view but that does also not give us the right to pass judgment. The first part of the book at the farm became repetitious and boring. I almost stopped reading at this point and it stopped me giving this book 5 stars.
title: powerful but repetitious.

author: Jane Swigart
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2021
review_content: Well, I’m struggling with what to write.  I found the book to be depressing and really hard to read, but I couldn’t stop reading, and,  in retrospect, I needed to read it.  I needed to get through every part of it to get to the final chapters which made it all worth it.  If even a small measure of it is factual, it was really something to read what our ancestors went through to survive the Great Depression.  The writing, the description of the land and the people, the characters, the ending..... a really really good book.
title: Not an easy read,  but a great read

author: xenots
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2021
review_content: WOW!  I'm lost for words right now. It's about dysfunctional families, life, struggles, over coming your worst fears and standing up for what's right.  It's about basic human survival. Stay strong with your believes and never stop regardless of all the road blocks ahead. LISTEN TO THE WHISPERS AND FOLLOW YOUR GUT.
title: Highly recommend for book clubs. GREAT book

author: Lita Perna
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2021
review_content: I loved the Nightingale which captured me from the first page. This novel is an effort to return to again and again. The female protagonist's initial victim-like  behavior was a predictable cliché from the start. I cheated and flipped to the final page. Sure enough she was hailed as a warrior. I will probably make an effort to read a few more chapters, but any novel that takes effort to get through so I can feel I got my money's worth, isn't worth it. I am sorely disappointed.
title: Disappointing

author: Amazon Customer
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2021
review_content: This book covers a period of time in our history that I learned about in passing. The Great Depression and The Dust Bowl are terms I am familiar with...but that I really had no idea what they looked like. This book offers a harrowing glimpse into that time.The suffering detailed in The Four Winds is simultaneously heartbreaking and hopeful. Hopeful that they will catch a break, that relief is within reach. As the story unfolds and nears the end...it is clear that the hope I felt as a reader was wrapped up in the love of this family. The love that is tested, over and over again. The love that perseveres. The love that grows, even as everything else is lost. The love that lasts a lifetime. Just beautiful...terribly beautiful.
title: An ode to Motherhood

author: Love to read
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2021
review_content: the story started out pretty good.  i was so glad i bought this book.  well, i'm about to just say: can't do this anymore!the characters are just boring and if i read one more page about the brutal weather conditions, i'm going to scream!really, 5 star people...what are you thinking?  i gave it 2 stars only because i really liked the beginning
title: why do i continue to read this

author: Mimi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 9, 2021
review_content: I have been reading Kristin Hannah for years and she never disappoints. This goes up at the top for one of my favorites. This time in history was so glossed over in school. They spoke of the crash in the market and the banks bot very little in the dusty bowl. These farmers lost everything over night and became slaves to the greedy corporate farmers of California. They had no chance of getting ahead but still worked their fingers to the bone just to feed their children. A story of strong woman with a dream to make their lives better.
title: The Four Winds.

author: Kristina Moore
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2021
review_content: I love Kristin Hannah but did not like this book. It was incredibly depressing. I understand the time period was difficult but I didn’t see any relief or happy ending for any of the characters. I just wanted it to end. Super disappointing.
title: Super depressing & disappointing read

author: Dami Roelse
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2021
review_content: The Four winds reads like. 3star hotel. All the pieces of the story are there, historical facts, opposing characters, story arc and a worthwhile story of survival. The story telling misses the dramatic touch, the building of compelling scenes and the showing of raw emotion that pulls a reader into the story. The story seemed too orderly, a series of events rolled out in historical sequence without the artistic touch. I can imagine the dreadful events in Elsa’s life but the author doesn’t pull me into them. Sorry I was hoping for a higher quality book after seeing all the enthusiastic reviews
title: 3star hotel

author: Anthony van Vliet
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
review_content: I really love author's other work, but it was a struggle to get through this book. I almost gave up on it several times. There are no added dimensions to the plot...this is like reading the diary of a person living through the dust bowl. Other than the main character, there is not much to the others. I found it exceedingly depressing and predictable.
title: Limited plot dimension, slow pace, predictable

author: josiep
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2021
review_content: Kristen Hannah seems to be incapable of writing a book that does not alter you in mind, soul and body. Each of her books has blessed, educated and left me clinging to her beloved characters, reluctant to let them go. How do I leave  Elsa, Loreda, Ant, Jack, Rose and Tony? It seems so impossible. Yet, I thank her for all the love that Elsa harvested and reaped, giving us lessons on how to thrive and survive on love when all else fails us. I will never forget that powerful lesson.
title: What a story!

author: Katie52
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2021
review_content: I loved this book, more than I expected.  The writing is beautiful and the research so detailed that I truly felt I was living in the Dust Bowl and barely surviving in the migrant camps and picking cotton under barbaric conditions. Steinbeck, of course, described this well in Grapes of Wrath. But Hannah has created such a strong main character, I was more than just hitching a ride alongside her on her journey. I was sharing the driving! I  wish I could read it for the first time again.
title: Completely Engrossing

author: Karen Harris
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 24, 2021
review_content: As a person who loves historical fiction, this book was eye-opening and informative. I have read many books focused on the Holocaust, world wars, but few books that focused on American historical events. I read this book quickly despite my demanding schedule.  The book pulled me in, maintained my interest, and focused on a period of history in our own country with hardships most of us have never endured. I appreciate the research and interviews that clearly formed the backbone ofMs. Kristin Hannah’s writing. It’s not light-hearted or easy reading as some have commented.  That theme is not the purpose of this book. It is a story of a fictional family that went through true American historical events less than a century ago. My maternal grandmother was abandoned by her husband during the depression and she was left with two young daughters - one of them my mother.  My grandfather’s (who left) family took them in just as in this book. I feel that this book expanded my awareness of why my heritage is from a long line of strong and independent women - because they had to be. Thank you Ms. Hannah. I had no idea the extent of what Americans went through to survive and the slavery imposed upon them. Well worth reading if you love historical fiction. I will be focusing on American themes on my journey of reading HFiction thanks to this book. Well done Ms. Hannah and thank you.
title: Well written and Informative

author: Alice Lewis
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2021
review_content: People down on their luck but determined to find a way forward. We see this even today in the people migrating to our country. They are trying to find a better life not a handout, a way forward for themselves and their children. Unless we are native Americans we are all of migrant roots. And even the native peoples ancient ancestors  migrated here from Asia across the Bering Straight. Judge less and help more.
title: American History

author: Movie Critic
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2021
review_content: This novel is amazing! I loved reading it and realizing a few things. First, the lockdown from COVID is nothing compared to what others have suffered in the past. Second, women are TOUGH BITCHES when they need to be. The protagonist has nerves of steel. And what a Mama Bear! She did everything to protect her kids. Her husband was a ne'er do well (as we used to say), but by gosh, she did whatever it took to feed and clothe her children. She did what she had to do. Period. I loved her!!
title: WOW!

author: tumbleweed
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2021
review_content: I had this book sitting quietly in my kindle, ready to read. And it took me awhile to get to it. But my god am I glad I did!!  It had been a very long time since I cried while reading a book. “Bridges of Madison County” came to my mind.Thank you for a loving history lesson book. I love the characters and can def relate as a mother myself!!As women we need to remember who came before us and paved the way with their blood sweat and tears. Thank you! ❤️
title: Unbelievably Heartbreaking and fabulous story

author: Elizabeth Suttles
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2021
review_content: Wow....just wow.  This is the first Kristin Hannah book I have read, but it will not be my last.  I absolutely HATE when books make me cry, but this book will go down as one of my all time favorites.  I was ugly crying the whole way through.  This book hit home how similar the times are now as they were during the Great Depression.  It saddens me that we, as Americans, have allowed greed to continue to rule our country, even after everything people went through in the depression.  We are supposed to grow from History, not repeat it.  I wish I had asked my Memaw more about what it was like when she was growing up.  She would have been around Loreda's age, and I thought of her throughout this whole book.  She too was a warrior.
title: Everyone should read this!!!
